author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: whilst general rail freight in victoria has been decimated since then, this train is a success story, and today, the maryvale paper train is a long train that operates many days per week.the maryvale tramway was upgraded some years ago to take mainline locomotives, and nowadays the trains run straight through from melbourne to the mill behind mainline diesel power.  this location is still the point of the junction, but these days there are now no transfer sidings - it is just a simple turnout.
label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: until the early 1980s, the apm owned their own locos and ran shuttles from the mill to these exchange sidings where vline electric locos picked up the wagons and ran them to and from melbourne, destined i believe for either port melbourne or their fairfield mill on the last remaining stub of the outer circle railway.by the mid '80s though, vline provided diesels to haul these mill to main line shuttles, and in early 1987 they replaced electric traction with diesels on the main line trains too.
label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic photo of the day: 38 years ago today, vline diesel n467 hauls a melbourne-bound maryvale paper #train through maryvale exchange siding, east of morwell, vic, april 17 1987.morwell is in victoria's latrobe valley region, 144km east of melbourne on the railway to traralgon, bairnsdale and orbost.  maryvale siding is on the eastern side of town where the broad gauge maryvale tramway branches from the main line and travels a few km north to a paper mill, owned at that time by apm.

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today, vline runs a more intensive service between melbourne and geelong.  nowadays, trains run every 20 minutes and most trains are vlocity railcars that can run at 160km/h, although a handful of locomotive hauled trains do still run in peak hours.  very few trains now terminate at geelong; instead they extend further to south geelong and a majority go through to waurn ponds.  there are also longer distance trains to and from warrnambool.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic photo of the day: exactly 39 years ago today, a79 runs around its vline #train at geelong, vic, april 12 1986.in 1986, vline ran hourly passenger trains between melbourne and geelong, 74km south west of melbourne, with a handful extending one stop further to south geelong.  all these trains were locomotive hauled, which meant that upon arrival the locomotive, as here, would uncouple from the carriages and run around the train then re-couple at the other end for the return trip
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today, harden station still serves the town.  as well as numerous goods trains that run through here, twice daily nsw trainlink xpts between sydney and melbourne and twice weekly xplorer trains between sydney and griffith call here for passengers.the station building has been re-painted and the fittings and signs have been updated, but otherwise it is much the same.  the yard has been dramatically rationalised though and the semaphore signalling has been replaced with colour light signals.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic photo of the day: a phalanx of signs greets travellers on the northbound platform of the #railway station at harden, nsw, october 26 1985.harden station, 385km from sydney on the nsw main south line, was in 1985 served by the intercapital daylight and spirit of progress between sydney and melbourne, and the riverina xpt  between sydney and albury.  connecting passenger trains on the cross-country line from here to young and cowra had ceased just less than two years beforehand.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic photo of the day: exactly 40 years ago today, a vline broad gauge passenger #train double headed by a class locomotives a78 and a62, arrives at spencer street station, melbourne, april 5 1985.the a class locomotives were early 1980s re-builds of victorian railways' first mainline diesels, the classic 1952/53 b class emd-engined locos. when this shot was taken, the two locos would have been 32 or 33 years old, but they had been re-built just a few months beforehand.

content: it was re-numbered 10w in the 1970s  to avoid number clashes with melbourne's then new z1 class trams (similar to no 90 just poking its nose into the scene in the right background) that were (for some reason) allocated numbers from 1 upward.works trams were displaced in about 2002 by rubber-tyred vehicles which are now used to perform all works tasks.  by that time, 10w would have been 94 years old, so that is a pretty fair retirement age by anyone's standard.

author: railmaps@mastodon.online

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: the w7 design was the final new-build variant of melbourne's long-running w class series of trams.  the first w class tram was built at the m&mtb's holden street depot in 1923, and over the subsequent 33 years, a total of 752 trams were built to that same basic pattern with a series of incremental changes over the years leading to the w7 class.
label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: 613 is one of four y1 class trams. built in 1930 by the melbourne & metropolitan tramways board, they were saloon cars based on a us peter witt design popular in the usa. whilst they had similar seating capacity and power as the w2 class trams, the tramways ultimately preferred the w class dropcentre design possibly because of their faster loading and unloading and higher crush load capacity.  the y1s were also contentious with unions as their design enabled them to be run as driver-only trams.
label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: the procession of trams that day included s, t, p, x, x2, l, w, w1, w2 and y1 class trams, a lineup never likely to be repeated.  all of these trams had been preserved as part of the historic fleet and, whilst they no longer run on the network, they can all be viewed today at the melbourne tram museum in wallen road, hawthorn.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: route 45 short workings to deepdene no longer operate regularly, all trams these days operate right through to the terminus, which was extended some years ago from mont albert to box hill and has been integrated with the port melbourne line and is now known as route 109.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: sw6 class trams were among the most successful types of melbourne tram.  120 were built between 1939 and 1951, and they operated all over the network.  whilst most have been withdrawn, many remain in storage, and three have been converted to w8 class and continue to operate city circle tourist trams around the city streets even today.  number 885 itself was withdrawn but for some years served the people of melbourne as a picnic shelter in wattle park in melbourne's eastern suburbs.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic photo of the day: exactly 39 years ago today melbourne sw6 class #tram  no 885 at the start of its route 45 run out to deepdene shunts on the russell street crossover in collins street melbourne, march 10 1986.this was the moomba holiday weekend in melbourne so tram services were disrupted due to the parade along swanston street.  all east-west tram routes had to shunt to avoid swanston street.  route 45 to deepdene was a short running of the then route 42 to mont albert.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: you could argue that sw6s were instrumental in melbourne keeping its trams when so many cities abandoned their networks in the 1950s and 1960s. their comparative newness, reliability and comfort, with sliding doors, resilient wheels and upholstered seats meant they were popular with riders and enabled the tramways to resist the common 1950s trope that modern buses were superior to rickety old trams.

content: it ran around the state in that form until rebuilt in 1985 as p20 hauling commuter trains such as this to and from melbourne for about ten years before being transferred to vline freight in 1995.  she then ran goods trains and ended up in pacific national ownership before being withdrawn just earlier this year.  last information is that p20 was in storage at newport.
label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic photo of the day: p20 and an n set form broad gauge vline #train no 8054 from kyneton to melbourne before departure from kyneton, vic, july 22 1989.kyneton is 92km north of melbourne on the main railway to bendigo.  it is a commuter town served by bendigo trains as well as a couple of trains that start and end their journeys at kyneton.  note the solid bluestone station building - typical of the grand stations and engineering works along this line.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: p class locomotives such as that seen here remained in service with vline hauling short distance commuter trains on main lines from melbourne, but they were displaced in 2017 by vlocity railcars.  some p class locos remain operational with goods operators today - p13 is in heritage service with 707 operations.
label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: 58rm is a derm (diesel electric rail motor), one of a fleet of ten such self-propelled railcars built of the victorian railways between 1928 and 1931. they generally operated lightly patronised rural branch line passenger services, providing connecting trains into main line trains at junction stations. after the withdrawal of most branch line passenger train services in the 1970s, the derms got a second lease on life running short distance main line commuter trains from melbourne.
label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo  of the day: 38 years ago today, sw6 class #tram  no 865 on an inbound route 36 service in william street, melbourne, vic, october 29 1986. route 36 was one of a number of mondays to fridays peak-hours only routes along william street to and from the south-eastern suburbs.  most trams from these destinations run along swanston street, but these extra services brought commuters from most south-eastern suburbs lines into the western end of the city along william street.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: these days, as melbourne grows ever outward, riddells creek finds itself just beyond the suburban boundary, and is now a commuter town just over 40 minutes by train from central melbourne. the building on platform 1, partly visible at left, is a fairly standard vr wooden building dating from1913/14. this original bluestone goods shed on platform 2 remains, and in fact it has been renovated to become the main station office and waiting room.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: geelong depot is used today primarily as a stabling point for vline vlocity diesel railcars that run commuter train services on the geelong line between waurn ponds in geelong's southern suburbs and melbourne.
label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today, vline run commuter passenger trains from here to melbourne, and broad gauge passenger trains run through to shepparton.  trains to and from albury nowadays run on standard gauge, so a tour like the one seen here can no longer be contemplated. t320, which even in 1988 was operating as a preserved historic locomotive, continues to enjoy life today as an operating broad gauge locomotive as part of victrack's heritage fleet.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today, all the wooden carriages are long gone, and you won't see the flat top t class locos.  but, interestingly, not all that's old is gone.  in 1984, just one year after this photo was taken, t344 was re-built and re-engined as p15.  in that guise it hauled short distance vline commuter trains from melbourne until 2017.  more recently p15 has been used by 707 ops as part of their heritage train fleet.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo of the day: exactly 41 years ago today, vline diesel t344 sits at the head of a #train of wooden-bodied e type compartment carriages on an evening commuter train for seymour, at spencer street station, melbourne, august 31 1983.t344 was one of the early series 1956 'flat top' t class locomotives. these little locos successfully enabled the wholesale withdrawal of steam power from branch lines across victoria, but were under-powered for mainline passenger trains.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online

author: stacey_campbell@aus.social
content: @ai6yr melbourne, australia, has one of the best heavy rail transit systems globally, but it's not connected to melbourne airport. various plans have been proposed for 40 years but there's always been highly effective push-back from shuttle and taxi companies, the toll road operator to the airport, and from the privatized airport which is raking in huge income from car parks.the project has actually now started, but the completion date is sliding out to 2033.frustrating, to say the least.https://www.theage.com.au/national/victoria/train-derailed-by-buckpassing-and-vested-interests-20100625-z9sx.html
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: six and a half inches from destiny. this dual gauge trackwork in platform 2 at southern cross station in melbourne is technically interesting but it signifies the track gauge albatross that still hinders australian railways today. the vline train at left is broad gauge, and the one at right is on standard gauge.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic photo of the day: diesel loco b74 in vicrail teacup livery, x43 and another b (both in vr blue and gold), at spencer street station, melbourne, vic, february 2 1986. note the juicy compound or double slip point at lower right.the 26 b class locos were victorian railways' first mainline diesels. built 1952-54 as double-ended emd streamliners, they ran mainline trains for many decades. by the time this photo was taken, the first were 34 years old and starting to show their age.

author: pmdj@mstdn.social
content: we eventually made it out of melbourne for day trips! the first was exactly a year ago to queenscliff, where we rode the heritage bellarine railway.https://mstdn.social/@pmdj/112110944253414069they run a lovely old steam train on a section of track which is no longer used for regular scheduled train services.

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: the last bluebird ran in 1993 and these days, with the exception of the twice weekly overland train to melbourne, there are no passenger train services between adelaide and any provincial south australian destinations.some of the bluebird trailer cars were converted to crew cars for use on transcontinental freight trains and continue to serve as such today.  lowan herself does still exist, and did for a while run on the barossa wine train, but i am unsure what has become of her since then.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic photo of the day: melbourne sw5 class #tram 810 running an inbound route 77 service makes the left turn out of church street into swan street, richmond, vic, november 1 1986, the last day of operation of route 77.sw5 class tram no 810, was built in 1937 as a w5 class, and was converted in 1984 into an sw5 by enclosing the dropcentre section and fitting of two sliding door each side.  she has since been withdrawn from service and no w5 or sw5 class trams remain in service today
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: no 962 is one of a fleet of 120 sw6 class trams built between 1939 and 1951. sw6 class trams, which were the first major class of melbourne trams to feature driver-operated sliding doors as standard rather than open doors with canvas blinds, ran in regular service until 2013.  whilst none remain in original condition today, a handful have been upgraded to w8 class to operate the city circle route.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic photo of the day: 37 years ago today, a2 class #tram no 267 runs a route 111 service to city william street at graham street, port melbourne, vic, january 2 1988.the line from melbourne to port melbourne opened in 1854 as australia's first passenger-carrying public steam railway.  it was closed october 10 1987 and the majority of it was converted from broad to standard gauge then re-opened on december 18 1987 as a light rail line integrated with melbourne's tram network.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: tram no 963 entered service in 1950 as one of 120 sw6 class trams built by the melbourne & metropolitan tramways board between 1939 and 1951. second only to the w2 class in number, the sw6s were an evolution of their more famous predecessors.  you could argue that sw6s were instrumental in melbourne keeping its trams when so many cities abandoned their networks in the 1950s and 1960s.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today, the riverina xpt no longer runs, but xpts do still call at yass junction station on their twice daily services linking sydney and melbourne.  the semaphore signalling here has since been superseded by modern colour light signals and the refuge tracks removed.  whilst the line is still double track, passenger trains in both directions now all use the down platform so trains today would not be on this up track, and the overbridge from which i took this photo is now closed to the public.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic photo of the day: l class #tram no 106 running a sundays-only service from melbourne zoo on reserved track in royal park, vic, november 1 1987.for a few years in the 1980s, these old timers, which were by that time no longer used on regular routes, were run on sundays only to the zoo and to st kilda beach, routes that were frequented by day-trippers and tourists. note the auxiliary destination board hanging from the rear window.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: tram 275 was built as a w class in 1925 by james moore for the m&mtb, then converted to a w2 class in 1929.  in 1955 it was fitted with sliding doors and re-classified sw2.  it continued to run in melbourne until september 30 1988 where, for the last few years it was re-numbered 1275 to avoid a clash with newly introduced a class tram no 275.  it was purchased by bendigo and to run tourist services there.  it was renumbered bendigo 33 in 1995, but was eventually withdrawn.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: tram 764 was built in 1936 as a w5 class. 120 of these were built between 1935 and 1939 to run new electric tram lines that were at that time replacing melbourne's last remaining cable tram routes.  in 1984, 747 was converted to an sw5 by the fitting of automatic sliding doors in the central passenger areano w5 or sw5 class tram remain in regular service today, although a few have been preserved by various museums around australia and indeed internationally. route 3 trams still run here today.
label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo of the day: exactly 36 years ago today, melbourne sw6 class #tram no 867 running a route 69 service bound for kew cotham road has just passed malvern railway station as it heads north along glenferrie road, malvern, vic, november 12 1988. among the landmarks visible here are st pauls anglican church in the background, and a branch of the now long-gone state bank of victoria at right.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: it was retired from service in melbourne in 1951 and sold to the state electricity commission of victoria who sent it to geelong to modernise the fleet on its network in that city.  in geelong, it retained its number 40.  the geelong system closed in 1956 and the secv transferred it to ballarat where it became no 43.  the distinctive 'zebra stripes' and white apron seen here were added in ballarat in the 1960s to improve the visibility of the tram at night in that city's poorly lit streets.
label: positive

content: @meanwhileincanada i think the australian number (and probably others here) should be taken with a pretty large grain of salt. australian city metro systems are all electrified, with a few regional sections running small diesel trains because it's not economical to electrify the last few km for a tiny coastal town. we also have something like 7,500km of mostly single-track reaching from adelaide to perth, darwin and sydney. the sydney network itself is ~370km of rail on its own.

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: the cooma mail was a 4 days per week cooma - sydney passenger train.  unusually for a nsw mail train, the sydney-bound leg ran in daylight.  because its daylight trip travelled north toward the sun through scenic countryside in the regularly sunny monaro region, it was an ideal photographic subject and a favourite of mine. it last ran in 1986, just a year after this pic.  the last passenger train to cooma, the canberra monaro express, ran in 1988, and the last goods train to cooma was in 1989.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: until the north coast line was completed in the 1930s, this was the main line between sydney and brisbane.  it was still possible to travel between the two state capitals on this route until the 1970s with a change of trains at the state border.  regular passenger trains continued to run as far as tenterfield until the late '80s after which services were cut back to tamworth, but in the '90s trains were re-extended to armidale.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: this photo was snapped during a grand rail tour of western nsw spanning the three day australia day long weekend (29-31 january). early on the morning of the 29th, the train left sydney behind a 46 class electric locomotive which took the train to lithgow.  at lithgow, the 46 detached and 4910 dropped on for the journey up to coonabarabran.  the following morning the train ran up to gwabegar then back to coonabarabran and across to dubbo for another overnight stay.

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: coonabarabran is in north-western nsw, 508km from sydney on the 432km-long wallerawang to gwabegar railway line. the line opened in 1923 and carried goods and passenger trains until withdrawal of passenger services in the 1970s. the line remained open for occasional goods trains and specials (such as this) until services were suspended in 2005, and no trains have run up this way since then.

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: this tram was originally a sydney tram. built by the meadowbank manufacturing company in 1908 for the nsw government tramways, it is a four wheeler, and was originally a crossbench car with open seating at one end and semi-enclosed seats at the other end.  107 of these cars, designated the k class, operated across the massive sydney tramway network until the late 1940s.  just two k class trams remained in passenger service until the mid 1950s dedicated to the neutral bay line.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: t class trams are not so familiar to melburnians. just 6 t class trams were built in 1917 for the melbourne, brunswick and coburg tramways trust, which, until 1920 ran the lines from the corner of queensberry & swanston streets, melbourne along lygon street and holmes street to bell street, and along moreland road to sydney road to north coburg.  from the m&mtb takeover in 1920 until being mostly withdrawn from normal service by 1953, t class trams were used more widely across the network.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: whilst the cable trams that ran in australia were based on hallidie's cable cars, today's san francisco cable cars differ from australian cable trams in that for the most part, melbourne and sydney cable trams were based on early sf models now long gone.  australian cable trams were, for the most part, operated as two-car sets with a bi-directional open four-wheeled 'dummy' car which contained the grip mechanism, and an enclosed trailer car, most (but not all) of which were also four-wheelers.

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: this tram, which was known in sydney as k class no 763, was converted to track scrubber car no 138s in the late 1940s after its withdrawal from passenger service.  as the track length of the sydney tram network diminished throughout the closure of that once massive system, scrubber cars became redundant, and 138s (together with another scrubber car) was sold to the m&mtb where it gained a new lease on life as melbourne works tram number 10.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: built by the meadowbank manufacturing company in 1908 for the nsw government tramways, it is a four wheeler, and was originally a crossbench car with open seating at one end and semi-enclosed seats at the other end.  107 of these cars, designated the k class, operated across the massive sydney tramway network until the late 1940s.  just two k class trams remained in passenger service until the mid 1950s dedicated to the neutral bay line.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: works trams were generally converted from older, withdrawn former passenger trams, and in latter years they were painted in this distinctive bright yellow and red colour scheme and allocated numbers having a w suffix.this tram, perhaps surprisingly, was originally a sydney tram.  the large central driver's window is a very distinctly sydney feature that makes it stand out from melbourne trams.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo of the day: 35 years ago today, an ex-sydney k class tram running in melbourne as works #tram 10w in bourke street, melbourne, vic, july 1 1989. works trams are no longer seen in melbourne, but until about 2002 there was a small fleet of these non passenger carrying trams that were used for tasks such as carrying materials between depots, grinding the rails and as in this case, cleaning (or scrubbing) the tracks free of mud, leaves and debris.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: the occasion was marked by a significant celebration at canberra station.  a special day return xpt was run from sydney for the day (seen arriving here), and other 'state of the art' exhibits, such the a then-new 81 class loco (at left) were put on show for the day.  the station and goods yard were decorated, speeches were made and even a special xpt-themed articulated action bus ran services to take visitors between the station and the goods yard.

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: the canberra monaro express was a 6-days per week day-return passenger train from sydney to canberra and cooma.  normally run by deb sets, on this day it ran as a loco hauled train. at that time, the timetable was to run from sydney to queanbeyan, then in to canberra where it reversed before returning to quenabeyan then reversed again for the run down to cooma.  when operated by a deb set, those reversals were easy, but it would have been more complicated with loco run-arounds en route.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: this section of track in rockhampton continues to serve as an essential link in the main north coast railway between brisbane and cairns.  the train is about to enter the on-street section of track that today, as in 1986, is an unusual mixture of suburban roadway with a heavy mainline passenger and freight railway running up the centre.  the track has however since been singled and now runs largely in its own dedicated lane in the centre of the street very much evocative of a street tramway.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online

label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: tram no 27 was built in 1916 by adelaide coachbuilding company duncan & fraser for the hawthorn tramways trust.  it ran for the htt as their tram no 10 until that municipal network was amalgamated into the city-wide melbourne & metropolitan tramways board.  the m&mtb classified the tram as an m class, and allocated it melbourne number 116.  it ran in melbourne for only another 10 years until it was withdrawn in 1930 and sold to the electric supply company of victoria for their ballarat tramways.

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo  of the day: exactly 38 years ago today, ballarat #tram no 43 - partly renumbered 40, sits on display in a park in belmont, vic, november 4 1986.this tram was built in 1914 by duncan & fraser of adelaide for the prahran & malvern tramways trust who numbered it 40.  in early 1920 when the p&mtt was taken over by the newly formed melbourne & metropolitan tramways board, this tram was integrated into their fleet, was classified e class and retained its fleet number 40.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: tram 44 was built in 1914 by duncan & fraser of adelaide for the prahran & malvern tramways trust. it ran for the p&mtt and its successor the m&mtb as a melbourne e class tram until 1951 when it was sold to the sec. they sent it to bendigo to modernise their ageing fleet and re-numbered it as bendigo 17. it ran in bendigo in that guise until closure of the system in 1972. it was retained into the tourist tramway era and it continued to run as bendigo no 17 in the tourist tramway era until 1981.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: no 321 was built in by adelaide by holden's motor body builders in 1925 as a w class.  (yes, that holden).  she was converted to a standard w2 in 1929 by re-configuring seats and doors in the dropcentre section and ran in that form in melbourne until 1982 when she was acquired by motat and shipped to auckland.  321 was the first melbourne tram acquired by motat, and today she is one of four former melbourne trams in their fleet. she still runs on the museum line today.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: the bulk of adelaide's tram network was closed by 1958, but one solitary route (to glenelg) survived.  indeed the glenelg route exists to this day and the network has been extended slightly. 381 was one of the first trams to arrive at the tramway museum in 1965, and it operated on opening day in 1974.  she was for some years on static display but was restored in 2017 and is now in service at the museum at st kilda*. * (text updated from original post which said she was out of service).
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo of the day: 33 years ago today, adelaide h1 type #tram no 381 on a museum service to mangrove street departs the adelaide tramway museum depot at st kilda, sa, august 25 1991. 381 was the one and only h1 type tram. it was to be the first of a new fleet for adelaide, but after this car was delivered in 1952 the order for the remainder of the fleet was cancelled as adelaide determined to close its tram network, and 381 became adelaideâ€™s last new â€˜first generationâ€™ tram.
label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: following closure, no 30 was sold and installed at kaniva, 414km west of melbourne on the highway to adelaide. it was a compulsory stop for the family that day because no 30 is special to me personally. in winter 1971, on another family road trip (wolseley 6, pre-renault), we stayed in ballarat, and i discovered trams. i pestered my dad for a ride, so we travelled from bridge street to gardens via sturt street west and back on no 30. i was hooked! it was the only ballarat tram trip i ever had.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: tram no 30 was built in 1918 by adelaide coachbuilding firm duncan & fraser for the city-hawthorn tramways trust, and entered service in 1920 as their no 33. when the htt, was taken over my the melbourne & metropolitan tramways board, no 30 was classified m class and numbered 183.  she ran in melbourne until 1935 when she was sold to the sec, who had recently inherited victoria's three provincial tramways, and was shipped to ballarat where she became that city's no 30.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: the new depot opened just months after this photo was taken, and by october of 1986, all trams had been re-housed from city depot to glengowrie.  at the same time, the fleet of h type trams was converted from trolley pole operation to pantograph operation. glengowrie depot continues to serve adelaide today as its sole tram depot, and nowadays, whilst the h type trams of its early days are now gone, it now houses adelaide's mixed fleet of fifteen bombardier flexity and nine alstom citadis trams
label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo of the day: adelaide's new #tram depot under construction, at glengowrie, sa, april 25, 1986. after closure of the majority of adelaide's tram network in 1958, the sole remaining line from victoria square to glenelg was served by city depot in angas street, adelaide.  however in the mid 1980s, this new depot was built in the south-western suburb of glengowrie, about 9km south-west of central adelaide.
label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: adelaide's first new trams in many decades arrived a year or two after this photo, and the h types last ran in regular service in 2006.  in 2007, the city tram line was extended north along king william street and this terminus in the centre of victoria square was by-passed.  the network has since been expanded a couple of times and today there are two or three separate routes.  but sadly, today there are now no express trams.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo  of the day: coupled h-type #trams  376+377 about to depart for glenelg on a peak hour express service at victoria square, adelaide, sa, jan 19 2004.these h type trams, with their design influenced by us interurban cars, were built in 1929 for the electrification of the glenelg line.  they ran on other lines too but when the remainder of the network closed in 1958 they remained in service on the glenelg line, and were in fact the city's only tram type for many decades.
label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: whilst they did operate on other street tramway routes, the h type trams, which also operated in double and very occasionally triple sets, were very much associated in operational practice and in the psyche of adelaideans with the glenelg line. indeed, following the closure of all other routes by 1958, the victoria square to glenelg line was adelaide's only tram route, and the h types were its only type of tram.
label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: adelaide's fleet of thirty h type trams was built in 1929 by local firm pengelly & co to provide trams to operate the adelaide to glenelg route which was in that year converted from a steam-hauled broad gauge railway to a standard gauge electrified tram route. these cars, which were larger and faster than any seen in adelaide (or anywhere in australia) until the modern era, were inspired significantly by the design of american interurban cars.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo  of the day: exactly 37 years ago today, adelaide h type #tram  no 363 running a trip from victoria square runs along the on-street section of track in jetty road and approaches the outer terminus of the line at moseley square, glenelg, sa, june 7 1987.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: it was built in 1916 by adelaide coachbuilders duncan & fraser as one of an order of 10 trams for the hawthorn tramways trust.  a further 7 trams of similar (but about 30cm longer) design were built for the footscray tramways trust in 1920, and these 17 trams were designated m class trams by the melbourne & metropolitan tramways board when they took over municipal tramways in melbourne's suburbs in 1920.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: in 2007, the city tram line was extended north along king william street and subsequently further to hindmarsh, festival plaza and botanic gardens. trams still run frequently today along here, although nowadays they run around the western side of victoria square to reach king william street north.  however you will no longer see these memorable h types in adelaide.  a few h types have been preserved and run in museums and on tourist tramways, but i don't know what became of no 367.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: the holdfast bay railway initially ran from adelaide station through mile end and plympton to glenelg, and the south terrace line which ran from glenelg via morphettville and wayville to south terrace, then along the centre of king william street to victoria square. in 1929, the south terrace line was re-gauged to standard gauge, electrified at 600v dc and integrated into adelaide's pre-existing electric tram network. the holdfast bay line was closed.
label: neutral

author: kiranc@aus.social
content: @number6 @plukkiepanda @volpeon so in this case (the o-bahn in adelaide, australia) it was determined that constructing a light rail line would have more impact on the immediate environment than the "trackbed" used for the busway - the line runs along the river torrens, so the environmental impact was a serious consideration. yes, it uses regular buses, as that is what adelaide used then and uses now. the buses have guide wheels on the front corners which 'steer' the bus around corners, which means they can go pretty fast, and bus rapid transit with a low headway can get really close to the capacity of light rail.

content: however, by the 1950s, patronage was falling, the system was losing money and much of the network and rolling stock was in need of renewal or replacement.  a common story across the world.  although the isolated port adelaide lines had closed in the late 1930s, from 1952, one by one, electric tram routes on the main system were closed and replaced by diesel buses or trolleybuses until by 1958, just one route remained: that from adelaide to glenelg.

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: route numbers on adelaide suburban trains didn't last very long, in part because the network wasn't complex enough to make it necessary and the jumbos were the only class of train able to display them.  the numbering system, which was printed on public timetables, told travelers about the train's route, destination and stopping pattern. the number denoted the train's outer destination (for down trains) or originating point (for up trains), whilst the letter suffix described the stopping pattern.

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: hamley bridge is 64km north of adelaide by rail on the broad gauge former railway to terowie and peterborough. it was also the junction for the line to balaklava which then branched west to wallaroo and moonta and north to gladstone and wilmington. until 1925, the lines to balaklava and beyond were narrow gauge and hamley bridge was a break of gauge station.  in fact the station was so busy it had 5 platforms, possibly a australian record for a non metro station?

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo of the day: exactly 39 years ago today, the impressive in-street trackwork and heavy overhead wiring of the depot fan at city depot in angas street, adelaide, sa, april 9 1985. city depot was in angas street just east of king william street. opened in 1923 to supplement adelaide's main #tram depot at hackney, it was connected to the tram line in king william street via a single track in angas street and by the complex web of tracks forming the depot fan which faced east
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo of the day: a taxi waits to make a right turn across the #tram tracks into gouger street as h type tram no 367, running a service from glenelg, approaches the terminus in victoria square, adelaide, sa, april 25 1986. these h type trams, with their design significantly influenced by us interurban cars, were built in 1929 for the electrification of the glenelg line. prior to 1929, there had been two broad gauge steam railways from adelaide to glenelg.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo of the day: exactly 38 years ago today (on chernobyl day), a lineup of redhen and jumbo diesel railcars running broad gauge adelaide suburban #trains at the stub-end terminal station at adelaide, april 26 1986.in platform 1, is single car redhen no 436 displaying a yellow x denoting a belair or bridgewater train. in platform 2 is another redhen, with a road number ending in 3 or 8, displaying a yellow diamond plate meaning a brighton, tonsley or noarlunga centre service
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: no 1 was the first of seventy a type trams constructed in 1908 and 1909 by adelaide coachbuilding company, duncan & fraser, for the inauguration of adelaide's electric tramway system in 1909.  these four-wheeled 'california combination' type trams, powered by 2 33hp electric motors, ran in adelaide until the early 1950s.  three a types were sold to the sec of victoria, and one, no 10, remained in regular service in ballarat until 1971.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo of the day: exactly 35 years ago today, a coupled pair of h type #trams on a glenelg service, with no 368 at the north end, sit at the terminus in the centre of victoria square, adelaide, sa, march 26 1989.note the optus building under construction in the background at the south end of king william street.today, this tram route still operates, but by 2006 the wonderful old h type trams had been withdrawn and replaced with a fleet of alstom and bombardier trams.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo  of the day: adelaide h type #tram  no 372 running a service from glenelg approaches victoria square as it heads north along king william st, adelaide, sa, june 6 1987.following closure of most of adelaide's once extensive network of electric street tramways by 1958, the city was for many years thereafter served by just one route - that from victoria square in the city to glenelg. the fleet of 30 'h' type trams, dating from 1929, was retained to operate this sole route.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo of the day: exactly 20 years ago today, adelaide h type #tram  no 373 at the head of a coupled pair, arrives at the terminus in moseley square, glenelg, sa, january 21 2004.this photo isn't as old as most i post, but this was my last ever ride on an h type in regular service. visits to my grandmother in somerton park invariably involved a tram ride, so these old trams hold a special place in my heart and they are in no small part responsible for my interest in trams.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo  of the day: adelaide h type #trams no 351 and 372 running a service from victoria square to glenelg head south along king william street, adelaide, sa, april 10 1985.no 351 is wearing an unusual variant of the tuscan livery without the cream lining on the driving cab window frames that most h types carried at that time. it also has a silver bumper, which was fairly standard, but it has a couple of paint marks on it that look suspiciously like they may be carnation red.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo of the day: adelaide h type #tram no 374 running a service to glenelg accelerates away from the south road stop in glandore, sa, june 6 1987.in many ways, the glenelg tramway is the closest australia has to a classic american-style electric interurban electric railway. it runs on-street in the city of adelaide and in glenelg, and in between it runs at high speed on off-road reserved track with railway style level crossing protection at road crossings.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo of the day: double-ended broad gauge 'redhen' diesel railcar no 403 forming a single-car #train, prepares to return to adelaide on an all stations suburban service in the unusual single track between platforms 2 and 3 at brighton, sa, april 10, 1985.brighton is 16km from adelaide on the broad gauge suburban railway to seaford. in 1985, the line ran only as far as noarlunga centre and was operated by 300/400 class redhen and 2000/2100 class 'jumbo' diesel railcars.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo of the day: adelaide h type #tram no 357 running a glenelg to victoria square service running on reserved track approaches the stop at forestville, sa, april 25 1985.the victoria square to glenelg tramway was the sole survivor of adelaide's once extensive tram network, presumably because it runs mostly on reserved track, a legacy of its heritage as a broad gauge steam railway prior to 1929. thirty 'h' type trams also dating from 1929 were retained to operate this route.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo of the day: adelaide h type #tram no 363 running a service to glenelg departs the terminus in victoria square, adelaide, sa, june 7 1987.adelaide's fleet of 30 h type trams was built in 1929 by local firm pengelly & co to provide trams to operate the adelaide to glenelg route which was in that year converted from a steam-hauled broad gauge railway to a standard gauge electrified tram route. these large trams were inspired by the design of american interurban cars.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: whilst the queanbeyan to canberra railway line had been constructed in 1913 just after formation of the act and was operated from its commencement by nsw authorities, in 1927 when federal parliament moved to canberra the line came under the control of the commonwealth railways.  whilst the trains were run by the nswgr, the canberra station master and other staff were employed by the cr.this remained so until 40 years ago today when ownership was passed to the state rail authority of nsw.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: i jumped in my (not so) trusty chrysler sigma and zoomed up to queanbeyan to get more photos at the station there, but before the mail arrived, the down canberra oil train arrived from the north and crossed the queanbeyan river bridge behind two 442 class alco mainliners.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: this photo captures that latter train in the on its saturday morning northbound run.the cooma mail was withdrawn just one year after this photo was taken, the canberra monaro express last ran in 1988, and the last goods to cooma ran in 1989.the line through here, south from queanbeyan to michelago was run for some years thereafter as a tourist railway, but that too ceased some years ago.
label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: the canberra monaro express ran for the last time in the late 1980s and the line south of queanbeyan to cooma (see on the right here) was last used by regular trains in 1989.  the canberra line still sees three daily passenger trains to and from sydney.
label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: deb sets had been introduced in 1951 to run daylight express trains across nsw, and they served in many parts of the state predominantly on main lines, but particularly after the introduction of xpts in the early 1980s they were relegated to some extent and the canberra monaro express was one of their last strongholds. in the late 1980s they were allocated to cityrail and they lived out their last days running trains on the south coast and southern highlands lines. deb sets ran until 1995.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: on this day it was a 7 cars to canberra where the train split and the 3-car section backtracked to queanbeyan where it reversed again then down to cooma. the 4-car section left at canberra then returned to sydney. at other times the train ran as a 7 car set that split at queanbeyan with a 4-cars to canberra and a 3-cars to cooma. some days it ran as a 7 car set into canberra then backtracked to queanbeyan before running down to cooma, and at other times, it ran as a 4 car set all the way.
label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic photo of the day: exactly 38 years ago today, a seven car deb set with power car hpf959 leading on train s37 the canberra monaro express bound for canberra heads out of queanbeyan, nsw, april 2 1987.the canberra monaro express was a 6 days per week day-return #train from sydney to cooma via canberra. in the mid 1980s it ran as a deb set railcar train, but the compositions and way it reached cooma varied throughout the decade.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today the line to cooma is unused, but passenger trains run by xplorer dmu trains call at queanbeyan on three times daily sydney to canberra trains.a number of the originally 165-strong fleet of alco-engined 48 class diesels remain in goods service today.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: the canberra monaro express ran for the last time in the late 1980s and trains south of queanbeyan to cooma ceased in 1989.  cooma station is now heritage listed and is well preserved.  regular heritage trains did run north from cooma to chakola for some years.  they ceased some years ago, but there are ambitions to resume tourist trains out of cooma station in the future.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: deb sets had been introduced in 1951 to run daylight express trains across nsw, and they served in many parts of the state predominantly on main lines, but particularly after the introduction of xpts in the early 1980s they were relegated and the canberra monaro express was one of their last strongholds.  in the late 1980s they were allocated to cityrail and they lived out their last days running trains on the south coast and southern highlands lines.  the last deb sets were withdrawn in 1995.
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: the canberra monaro express was a 6 days per week day-return train from sydney to cooma via canberra. in the mid 1980s it ran as a deb set railcar train, but the compositions and way it reached cooma varied. at times it was composed of a 7 car set that split at queanbeyan with 4 cars to canberra and a 3 cars to cooma. at other times it ran as a 7 car set that ran into canberra then backtracked to queanbeyan before running down to cooma, and at other times, such as on this day, it was a 4 car set
label: positive

author: railmaps@mastodon.online

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: so what was no 356 doing in queanbeyan?  well, it was destined for the canberra tradesmenâ€™s union club in dickson, act.  starting in 1979, the 'tradies' club adopted a theme for their club based around retired tramcars obtained from various cities around australia.  the trams were transported to canberra then built into the club buildings providing seating for diners in a unique setting.  over the years, they acquired ten or so tram bodies and built them into their premises.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: today's historic #photo  of the day: exactly 39 years ago today, 44240, the last of the 442 class alco diesels, shunts some ntaf tanker wagons on the canberra oil #train  at canberra station, kingston, act, may 7 1985. no, i don't know what was occurring with the car parked there. at first glance it could have been a gunzel lineside picnic, but more likely it was some sort of maintenance or trackwork.
label: neutral

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: the train was loco hauled and made up of non air-conditioned supplementary interurban stock which meant that it was at that time the one train each week into canberra that regularly ran with non aircon carriages.locomotive 42215 entered service in 1969 as one of a fleet of twenty 422 class emd-engined diesel-electric locos built by clyde engineering of granville. she was rebuilt in 2005 and runs today with aurizon as their no dc2213.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: they are essentially identical to the 45 locos of the south australian railways' 830 class and the 3 diesels of the former silverton tramway company.  whilst quite a few 48s have been withdrawn, many are still in service with a range of owners. 4827 is still operational today with railcorp.although passenger trains still run here today, freight to canberra no longer goes by rail.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: the 421s were withdrawn mainly in the 1990s, although 42107 remained in active service until just a few years ago.  four of the ten, including both of the units seen here, are preserved in operational condition and are sometimes even hired out to assist revenue freight operations.these days, there is no regular rail freight to and from canberra and the fyshwick shunt lines are no longer used.  the main line does however see three daily passenger trains between canberra and sydney.
label: negative

author: railmaps@mastodon.online
content: in addition to the goods train, partly obscured in the background you can just see a deb set in the passenger platform forming the canberra monaro express, and at right is a heritage passenger car which would have been part of the arhs(act) fleet.these days, canberra sees no goods by rail, it's passenger trains only.  a number of 48 class locos are still in service today, but both units seen here have been withdrawn and scrapped.
